cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
Asturias will leave Suez about February 7.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Suez about February 21.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Omrah" will leave Port Said January 27
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Port Said February 10

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
*Special reduced rates during Summer season.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.
For all information apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Suez about April 11th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, will leave Port Said about April 14th.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships, Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG ;) weekly from ANTWERP every 4 week: from BORDEAUX direct to ALEXANDRIA: | homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBURG Goods forwarded at through-rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Lading to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, eto, Special facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc from Alexandris via Rotterdam And Hamburg to German manufacturing towns Por tarif and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STR088. Alexandria Agent -The following are expected as Alexandria Feb. 68.9 "Andro" from Hambourg, Sound for Rotterdam and Hambourg. -9.8. Volos" now in port disebarging bound for the Syrian Coast on or about the 27 inst. 15-9-907

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
SALOON FARE £12. Special summer season rates £10. Port Said to Marseilles £7.
S.S. AMARAPOORA 6600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about January 31, 1908.
Due in London or Liverpool in 13 days.
The saloon accomodation is amidships, and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Lights, and all have the latest improvements.
For further information, apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: SUDAN DEVELOPMENT & EXPLORATION COMPANY, LIMITED
div.p: KHARTOUM: CAIRO Office, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. Shipyard for construction of sternwheel steamers, barges, stream, motor launches, etc. Contractors for supply and erection of all classes of machinery, buildings, irrigation pumps, etc.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum.-Moderate fares.
Specially Reduced Rates for residents of Egypt by Tourist Services during November and December. First sailing November 13th.
WEEKLY FREIGHT SERVICE FROM CAIRO TO ASSUAN AND HALFA.
Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

div.head: COMPTOIR NATIONAL D'ESCOMPTE
div.p: DE PARIS.
CAPITAL: 150,000,000 frs,-£ 6,000,000 FULLY PAID UP. — HEAD OFFICE: 14, Rue Bergere, Paris
Alexandria Branch 11, Rue Cherif Pacha.—40 Branches in Paris, and 112 Throughout France.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

Ordres de Bourse. Reports sur valeurs égyptiennes, Avances sur marchandises et sur titres, Emission Lettres de Crédit, traites, chèques.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d'Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

ALEXANDRIA, 2 Mohamed Aly Square.— CAIRO, 19, Sharia el Manakh.
The Bank undertakes every description of Banking business on favourable terms. 18-4-907

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.
div.p: Head Office : Athens — Capital 20,000.000 (Fully paid up). — Reserve 1,000,000.

Branches: London 55-58 Bishopsgate-street Within, Alexandria, Cairo, Constantinople, Smyrna, Candia, Canea, Piraeus
Patras, Yolo, Syra, Calamata. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits,
3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 80 to P.T. 20,000. 19-1-907

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,500,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah, Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street). La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

div.head: IONIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA BRANCH, RUE ADIB. (ESTABLISHED 1839)

HEAD OFFICE: LONDON.–HEAD OFFICE for GREECE: ATHENS.– BRANCHES FOR GREECE: CORFU, PATRAS, CEPHALONIA, ZANTE, PIREUS, TRIPOLITZA.– AGENCY: NAUPLIA.
The IONIAN BANK LTD. transacts all ordinary banking business such as:

Advances on securities, merchandise, warrants, etc. Buying and selling of exchange on all principal centres abroad. Issue of drafts, letters of credits and telegraphic payments. Purchase and Sale of Securities. Current accounts are opened and: deposits at sight and at fixed dates are received on the following terms: 3 0/0 for deposits at 6 months notice; 4 0/0 for deposits at 1 years notice. 14-8-908

div.head: BANQUE DU CAIRE, LIMITED,
div.p: CAIRO.
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD.

SCHLESWIG will leave ALEXANDRIA at 29 January; 12, 26 February; 11, 25 March.
The following steamers are intended to leave PORT-SAID:

row.cell: HOMEWARD : for Bremen Hamburg via Naples, Genoa, (Gibraltar), Southampton, Antwerp.
OUTWARD: for CHINA and JAPAN via SUEZ, ADEN, COLOMBO, PENANG, SINGAPORE.
For AUSTRALIA via SUEZ, ADEN, COLOMBO.

div.p: Alexandria for Smyrna, Constantinople and Constantza. Departure from Alexandria at 4 p.m. by the twin-screw S.S. Impartial Traian on the 31st January. 27th March and 17th. "Romania" 14th February, 13th March and 24th April, "Dacia" 28th February and 10th April. Direct coincedence at Constantza with the Berlin and Paris-London express-trains. Rapid service for merchandise at low rates. Circular tickets issued to all parts of Europe.
FOR FURTHER PARTICULARS APPLY TO THE AGENTS OF THE
NORDDEUTSCHER LLOYD at Cairo, Alexandria, Port-Said and Suez.
OTTO STERZING, Agent In Cairo, Opera Square.
C. H. SCHOELLER, Agent In Alexandria, Cleopatra Lane.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd
div.p: Weekly Mail Steamers from ALEXANDRIA to BRINDISI, TRIESTE (VENTOR). leave Saturdays at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in connection with the morning Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. A Train de Luxe leaves the same evening, 6:35 p.m. for Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende, and London. Arrival at London on Friday 5:12 p.m.
Weekly Intermediate Mail Steamers
leaves Alexandria to Brindisi and Trieste every Thursday at 4 p.m.
Syria-Caramania Cyprus Service

weekly Mail Steamers leave Alexandria every Sunday 3 p.m. for Ports Said, Jaffa, Caifa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Alexandretta, Mersins, Larnaos, and Limassol. N.B. During the present Quarantine restirctions boats leave Alexandria Sundays 2 p.m. proceed from Port Said to Beyront directly, thence to Jaffa, Aaifa, Tripoli, etc.
For information apply to the Co's Agencies: Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Cairo, Helouan, Port Sudan, Khartum, Messrs. THOS COOK & Son Ltd etc

div.head: Newly Discovered MSS of The Bible.
div.p: "Four newly discovered MSS. of the Bible were reported at the meeting of the Archæological Institute of America." says the New York "Nation," "Prof. H. A. Sanders, of the University of Michigan, reported on four manuscripts of the Bible, now in the possession of Charles L Freer, of Detroit. The manuscripta were bought by Mr Freer early in 1907 in Egypt. They were probably buried or lost at the time of the Moslem conquest in 639 A.D. At any rate the manuscripts all date that period, nor, in the opinion of Professor Sanders, do they contain any inarks of a second hand even, which can be placed later than this date. "Two of the manuscripts are in a large ancial hand, two in small, and there are other variations sufficient to convince Prof. Sander that the individual manuscripts were written at different dates, ranging from the third to the sixth century. He refers to the manuscripts by the Roman numerals I, II, III, and IV. Manuscript I now contains Deuteronomy and Joshua; Genesis to Numbers inclusive, which it once contained, are missing. It is next to the oldest of the four manuscripts, and presents an exceptionally accurate text of this portion of the Septuagint. Manuscript II, contains the Psalms. Although it is the oldest manuscript of the four, and is badly decayed, large portions of every Psalm will prove recoverable. A comparison of a portion of the text shows that it is one of the best manuscripts of the Psalms in existence; in the large portions where the Vaticanus fails, it is perhaps the very best. "Manuscript III. contains the four Gospels entirely. It was probably written in the fifth or sixth century, and contains many interesting variant readings. It is most important, however, because it contains the following extra paragraph : "And they answered, saying that this age of unrighteousness and unbelief is under the power of Satan, who does not permit the things which are made impure by the (ovil) spirits to comprehend the truth of God (and) his power. For this reason, "Reveal thy righteousness now," they said to Christ, and Christ said to them: "The limit of the years of the power of Satan has been fulfilled, but other terrible things are at hand, and I was delivered unto death on behalf of those who sinned in order that they may return to the truth and sin no more, to the end that they may inherit the spiritual, indestructible glory of righteousness (which) is in heaven." "This new paragraph was known to St. Jerome, and the first few lines of it are oited in Latin translation. It has long been held that Mark xvi. 8-20 was a state addition to the Gospel, thought to have been borrowed from some other unknown Gospel near the end of the second century. This new manuscript probably presents the original form of that part of the lost Gospel, which, mutilated, was added to Mark. The reason for the omission is quite apparent, as the new verse contains the statement that the destruction of sin in the world is near at hand. This idea is found in the epistles of Peter and Paul, but the four Gospels do not have it, and it is avoided by the later Church writers. "Manuscript IV. is only a badly decayed fragment. It once contained Acts and the Epistles, but not Revelations. It is an older and better manascript than the four Gospels, and its readings will be of value."

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, CAIRO.
div.p: Strictly family Hotel. Built in 1904. near the Railway Station Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation
29242-26-11-90 J. VOCLES, Propr. Manager.

div.head: The Watfo Administration
div.p: The Superior Council of Wakfs will meet tomorrow in Cairo under the presidency of Has. san Pasha Rushdi.

div.head: The Republican Party
div.p: It is announced that the party of the Republic is about to issue a monthly review in support of their policy.

div.head: Cholera Precautions
div.p: A credit of LE 7,000 has been granted to cover the expenses to be incurred for the precautionary measures against cholera.

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: The following telegram has been received from Athens - "Medical inspection in lieu of quarantine for arrivals from the Mediterranean ports of Egypt."

div.head: Cobbo Boy's Transferment
div.p: Cobbe Bey, who recently transferred from the Alexandria Police Force to the Inspectorate of the Interior, has also been given an increase of salary to LE 550 per annum.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre
div.p: The performances given by Door Leblane at the Alhambra theatre are proving an enormous success; indeed this famous artist and his troupe are thoroughly supporting the fame they have attained.

div.head: New Crimes Bureau
div.p: A new office for control of crime in Egypt has been created at the Ministry of the Interior. Mr. Hornblower has been appointed director and Hashim Bey, late of Alexandria Public Security, chef du bureau.

div.head: The Brindiel Mall.
div.p: The mail for Europe vin Port Said and Brindisi will be made up at the G.P.O. Alexandria, at 8.10 p. m. on Sunday 26th for ordinary correspondents, at noon for money orders and insured articles and at 6 p. m. on Saturday 25th for parolees.

div.head: A Noted Violinist
div.p: Mr. Marsick, the noted violinist, gave a most enjoyable concert last night with the ad of Dr. Frey, Mr. P. Erlich, Madame Jesumann, and Mr. Jacot des Combes. We are glad to learn that Mr. Marsick will give a matinée concert on the 31st inst, when doubtless all lovers of music will flock to hear him.

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: Eight fresh cases of plague were recorded for the week ending January 21st, four at Minieh, three at Deirout, and one at Tantah. During the last 24 hours four cases have been discharged from hospital, two at Minieh and two At Deirout, one death being reported from the latter town. Twenty cases are now under treatment and the total for the month of January up to the 21st inst. was forty eight.

div.head: Ball at Khartoum
div.p: On the 17th inst. the Royal Engineers, E.A, gave a ball at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum. The hotel was beautifully decorated on that Occasion, mostly by the officers themselves who took great deal of trouble to make the ball successful. The gardens were very artistically illuminated. 180 set down for supper, which WAS served in the open air. The croquet lawn of the Hotel was converted into a huge drawing room. Dancing went on till 3 a.m.

div.head: Lamplough's Ploturee
div.p: Mr. Lamplough's exhibition of water-colour drawings at the Hotel d'Angleterre continue to attract a large number of people, and to his already perfect collection he has now added the sketches which he has made since his arrival in Cairo a short while ago. A feature of his work of this season will be painting of a series of well-known scenes of Cairo which the hand of time and the exigencies of modern life have doomed to destruction. All of us know and appreciate Mr. Lamplough's genius in reproducing the scenes peculiar to this country, and this latest collection of disappearing Cairo should prove of great value.

Hail to the spirit of liberty-Sousa

div.head: Egypt's Trade
div.p: November Customs Returns

During last month the value of goods imported into Egypt was L. E. 2,383,904, being LE. 210,976 less than December 1906, while for the year with an import value of L. E. 25,404,576 an increase of L. E. 2,089,283. is shown. Last month the exports totalled LE 3,868 007 against LE. 4 290,118 during December 1906, and since the 1st of January L. E. 28,013, 185 against L E 24,877,280. Classifying the various imports and exports we get the following figures for the year:-- Animals and animal foods -- Imports L E. 1,284,811; Exports L.E. 131,010. Skins and works in skins. Imports L B. 464,637; Exports I. B 148,256. Other animal products--Imports L.B. 92,476 Exports L.E. 110,274. Cereals, vegetables, and corns. - Imports LE. 2,963,931; Exports L.E. 3,189,506. Colonial roots and drugs. - Imports L E. 759,495 ; Exports L E. 113,823. Spirits, liquors, and oils - Imports L. E. 1,151,518; Exports L E. 13,957. Chiffons, papers, and books-Imports L E. 405,357 ; Exports LE. 19,725. Wood and coal. -- Imports 3,407,021 ; Ex | ports of wood L.E. 17,909. Stone, earth, Wessels, glasses, and crystals. Imports L. E. 774,420 ; Exports L.E. 5,100. Tinctures and colours. -- Imports LE 291,969 ; Exports L.E. 23,859 Chemical and medicinal products and perfumes. - Imports L.E. 762,111 ; Exports LE 28,753. Textile industries. -- Imports LB-7,006,851 Exports (cotton included) LE. 23,782,570. Metals and work in metal. - Imports LE. 3,960,584 ; Exports LB 3,906. Various articles, - Imports LE 2,083,075 Exports L.E. 81,528. Taking the total imports and exports for the principal countries for the year, we having the following figures : England - Imported L E. 8,705,917, Exported L E 15,237,411. Prance-Imported LE. 3,227,669 ; Export ed LE. 2,049,000, Turkey ---Imported LE. 2,973,108, Exported LE. 337,410. Austro-Hungary --Imported LE. 2,059,423; Exported LE 1,315,397.. Germany-Imported LE. 1,392,381 x Ex. ported LE. 2,252,954. Italy -Imported LE. 1,361,457 ; Exported LE. 791,044. Russia --Imported LE. 676,868 ; Exported LE. 1,599,580. - Greece-Imported L.E. 342,322 : Exported LE. 24,729.

div.head: Exchange of Specie
div.p: The total of specie imported last month was LE 498,818 as compared with LE. 1,515,659 in December 1906. During the year the import of specie was LE 7,768,190 as compared with LE 9,077,402 last year. Of the L.E. 7,768,190 imported during the year of LE. 4,806,074 came from England and LE. 1.446,625 from Turkey. The specie exported during last month was LE. 38,320 as compared with L. E. 40,714 in December 1906, and for the year the figures are L E 4,736,*89 and L.E. 2,067,706 respectively for 1907 and 1906. Of the exported specie during the year LE 2,118,215 went to England LE. 1,726,828 to India, LE. 488,885 to Turkey, and L E.361,680 to France.

div.head: Cigarette Trade
div.p: The total export of cigarettes during December was 44,980 kilos, as compared with 46,240 in December 1906 and from the 1st of January to 31st December the figures recorded for 1907 and 1906 respectively are 491,894 kilos, and 590,047. Of the 491,894 kilos, exported during the past year 153,786 went to Germany; 87,780 to England ; 69,015 to British possessions in the Far East; 44,350 to Austro-Hungary; 25,874 to China and the Far East; 23,221 to France; 14.240 to America ; and 12,096 to Belgium.

div.head: The Khedive
div.p: The Khedive, who attended prayers at noon today at Al Montazah mosque, will return to Cairo this evening.

div.head: The Assouan Dam
div.p: The foundation stone for the heightening of the Assouan dam was laid yesterday by Hussein Pasha Fakhry, Minister of Public Works. Ahmed Bey Kamel, mudir, and the mamour were also present to assist at the ceremony.

div.head: Paris-Geneva House
div.p: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her spring models at the Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria until the 25th inst.

div.head: Windsor Hotel
div.p: Facing the sea on the new quay of Alexandria
First-Class Hotel
Lately Built and Furnished
Tiers P.T. 50 per day

div.head: Merchant Seamen's Home
div.p: New Year's Treat

The annual New Year's Treat provided by the Ramleb ladies for seamen was given at the T Home on Wednesday last. The occasion is a very popular one with the men, and is looked forward to by those who have the good fortune to be, at the time, arriving at the port. As on so many prior anniversaries, the entertainment was organized by Mr Mose who had proved into the service many willing helpers. The lørge hall was decorated with tags lent from ships in the harbour, and with greenery supplied by Mrs Moss and Mrs. Cratton, the Arrangement being most effectively carried out by Captain Dingle (the manager of the Hne) and his assistants. The front of the pla prm presented a most pleasing effect, borrod with clumps of arum lilies. During the per each man was presented with #paokot of tobacco and a New Year's card (a personal gift from Mrs. Mose) and a buttonhole. Some 180 men did justice to a repast consisting of turkey, bam, joints, fruit, cake and tes, at the concert which followed an enthusiastic audience numbering with late comers, at least 250, testified their appreciation by hearty applause. Some members of the Blind School were present and appeared to enjoy the music. The musical part of the entertainment was again arranged by Mr. Hilary Moss the programme being as follows, many res being demanded. Miss H. Wilson, Piano solo. Mr. D. Allen, song, "Pinkerton's role Pills." Miss Hewat and Miss K. Murphy, violin duet. W.J.B. Clarke, song, "Cabal River." Mrs. EG C. Moss, song, "Sunbeams." Mr. H.E.C. Moss, song, "Lucky Jim." Miss B. Murphy, song, "The Kerry Dance." Mrs.J. Hicks Paull, Recitation. "The Alarm." Mr. Aydon, song. Captain Gardner, song, 'Of he went at seven in the morning." Mr. D. Allen, song, "The Coster's Mansion." Mr. J.B. Clarke, song, "I love a Lassi Mr. T. Ryanı'', song, "I was watching 'en." Mr. H.E.C. Moss, song, "Teasing." The piano accompanists were Miss H. Wilson (who worked exceedingly bard), Mrs. Hicks Paall and the Rev. EH. Blyth. At the conclusion Mr. Blyth, who had acted As chairman, called for three cheers for the Rainleh ladies and for all who had taken part in the cocoert. The response was tremulous, even for a Seamen's Home gathering three cheers more were given for the chairman and the evening closed by all joining in singing the National Anthem. The list of contributors to the feast in as follows: Mrs. Alderson, Mrs. C.H. Alderson, Mrs. Alex. Alderson, Mrs Andrews, Mrs. Douglas Allen, Mrs J.T. Atkin., Mrs. and Miss Atkin., Mrs. Lang Anderson, Miss Batoheller, Mrs. Horace Bell, Mrs. Birch, Mrs. Birley, Mrs. Borchgrevinck, Mrs. Buckley, Mrs Bull, Mrs. E. D. Carver, Mrs. 8. H. Carver, Mrs. Peroy Carver, Mrs. Ralph Carver, Mrs. Chataway, Mrs. Clarkson, Mrs. Crafton, Mrs. Cafwen, Mrs. H. Dickson, Mrs. Dorling, Mrs. Els arth, Mrs. Macpherson Grant, Mrs. F. C. Har den Mrs. Hewat, Mrs. Kelham, Mes n e, Mrs. Manley, Mrs. Mann, Mrs. les worth, Mrs Moss, Mrs. E. G. C. Moss, Mrs. Murray, Mrs. Parkinson, Mrs. Hicks Paell, Mrs Percival, Mrs. Pringle, Mrs. Richmond, Mrs. Roffer, Mrs Sandwith, Mrs Satow, Mrs. Soott, Mrs. Gilbart Smith, Mrs Strickland, Mrs. Swinglehurst, Mrs. Trelawney. Mrs. Tyrrell, Mrs. Van Horne, Mrs, William, Mrs. YE Williams

div.head: The Abdin Incident
div.p: The Sheikh Razi incident continue to arouse the keenest excitement and inte in native circles and contradictory rumours as usual published and repeated as facts i rery direction. If all the versions current the native Press are accurate then we are faced by the fact that Sheikh Razi was and is, at one and the same time, a bigoted reactionary and a pestilent revolutionary, an impious wretch and a virtuous cleric, that he was expelled from Khedivial reception on the ground of a perenal quarrel with a member of the Maieh Sanieb, and that he lett Abdin on his own motion on hearing that H. H. The Khedive declined to receive him, etc. etc. In any case, it is quite certain that a group of Ulema who had made certain complaints concerning the administration of the Al Azhar University, was admitted to the presence of his Highness at the Courban Liram reception and by him severely reprimanded. Their excuse was the usual one - "it was the other boy that did it, Sir, not me," and Sheikh Razi was held responsible. "Al Akhbar" adds that the Sheikh who has been loud in his complaints was recently informed that if he continued to discuss his grievances in public berould be degraded from his office. Meanwhile "Al Zaber" deplores a national calamity and brings out funereal columns with the deepest and blackest borders and the non-Moslem public demands more anxiously - who is Sheikh Razi "What has be done." Can "Al Moayad" or "Al Garida" give us a good account of the incident and its causes t"

div.head: Cheap Gas from Common Fuels
div.p: for Engines, Manufacturing, Furnaces, Pumping, Irrigation, Incandescent, Lighting and Generation of Electricity. Lane's Producers are available for Land, River or Ocean Service. Agents required. Address Howard Lane, 125 Edmund Street, Birmingham, England.

div.head: Letter to the Editor
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - free discussion.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Company
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir --Referring to the letter signed "Observer" in your issue of yesterday I beg to state that the statutes of the above named company provision is made for operating "dans des pays limitrophes à l'Egypte'' and the opening of business in Cyprus was voted in due form at a general meeting of shareholders held a few months after the company's formation. As on this point "Observer" seems to have misunderstood the letter signed by myself and colleagues which appeared in your number of the 22nd instant, others of your readers may have likewise done so. You will therefore find room for this rectification in your columna. There may possibly be cases in which the suggestions of "Observer" might prove exceedingly pertinent and useful, but they are not of application to the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co. The success of the company in Cyprus will depend on the degree to which intelligence and a rigid economy are exercised in the administration there, but the directors were unquestionably entirely within their rights in opening business in the island. Faithfully yours, DUKE BAKER.
Alexandria, January 24th

div.head: Egyptian Bonded Warehouses
div.p: The Egyptian Bonded Warehouses Company Limited have already begun working the freight service of the Express Nile Steamers Limited. There are fourteen steam barges and some tenders belonging to the Express Nile Company. The Bonded Warehouses have also come to an arrangement with the Hamburg AngloAmerican Line in regard to Nile freight traffic whereby there will be no cutting of rates in future between the two companies. Bonded Warehouses has purchased a large piece of land on the banks of the Nile at Boulac with a frontage of 120 metres. A quay and general warehouses are to be built immediately for landing and receiving goods by river.

div.head: The Cholera
div.p: False Report in "Times"

We are astonished to read the following report in the weekly edition of our London contemporary the "Times" : "A bulletin issued at Cairo says that 27 cases of cholera have occurred. At Mecca there have been 241 deaths, but none at Jeddah." We can safely assert that no such bulletin was issued, as there has as yet been no case of cholera either in this country or in Sudan. We trust that our contemporary will immediately rectify their error, which may prove deplorably detrimental to Egypt. The report will be eagerly seized upon and enlarged by those who are responsible for booming rival winter resorts, and, emanating from the paper which has the highest standing in the world of journalism, will be relieved by all who read it. We trust that in the interests of the Egyptian I public the "Times" will give prominence to an emphatic contradiction of so damaging and so false a report. The upmost possible precautions are being taken by the authorities to exclude the disease, and, though its advent is possible, it is at the same time probable that we shall escape it altogether. We greatly deplore the fact that the first newspaper of the world should have given publically to this incorrect news, the effect of which no one can at present judge.

div.head: Semiramis Hotel
div.p: A goodly assortment of people favoured the Semiramis on Wednesday evening both for dinner and the dance afterwards; & very great improvement being noticed in the condition of the ball room from week to week. Several parties came over from Ghezireh, and there were quite a number of Cairo residents and visitors from the other hotels in addition to those who are already staying at the Semiramis which like the rest is filling up fast. Amongst those present were :- Baron Oppenheim, the Count and Countess Walth meister, Count Koziebrodski, Lady and Miss Allen, Mr. and Mrs. Hall Caine, Colonel and Mrs. Parker, Major A. Saunders, Mrs. and the Misses Coles, Captain and Mrs Darell, Mrs. and Miss de B. Carey, Princess Irene Duleep Siugh, Major Stevenson, Mr. and Mrs. Appleton, Mr. Mrs. and the Misses Parbury, Mrs. Hornblower, Miss Smith, Countess of Rosslyn, Mr. Kenneth Speir, Mr. McNeill, Mr Mrs, and Miss Joseph, Mr. Mrs, and Miss Devonshire, Mr. and Mme. Tuan Campang, Mr. and Miss FitzClarence, Dr. Tribe, Mr.R. G. Orred, Baron de Villenfangue, Mr. and Mme. Cattaui, Mr. and Mrs Alexander, Menards. Adda, Mme Aghion, Messrs. Heller, Mr. and Mme Hochappel, Captain Kennedy, Colonel Cunningham and family, Mr. and Miss Rees, Mrs. and the Misses Moroom, Captain and Mrs Legard, Miss Logard, Mraj and Miss Ruffer, Mr. and Mrs. Tillard, Misd Monis, Mrs. Bohalez, Miss Frost, Mr. Gunter, Mr. Flower and many officers from the various regiments.

div.head: Zizinia Theatre
div.p: "Lohengrin"

With the production of Wagner's "Lohengrin" the Societa Artistica of Alexandria have placed before their ever appreciative audience perhaps the most successful attempt this season. The opera itself is too well known to require mach comment at this period. It might be of interest however to remark that Lohengrin, Knight of the Holy Grail, is introduced as a symbol of Christianity defeating the Frieslandish heathenism in the wiles and machinations of the sorceress Ortrud. After the splendid performance of Signorina Salomca Crucsenski in "Madame Butterfly" it was a foregone conclusion that her "Elsa" would be, at least, in no degree inferior to any previous interpretation of the character on the Zizina stage. Last night's production clearly proved this. Her performance was throughout, artistic in the extreme A delightful rendering of one of Wagner's tenderest compositions, a rendering overflowing with inexpressible sweetness and played with perfect grace. As "Lohengrin" Signor Italo Cristalli met with very hearty appreciation. He contributed considerably to the entire success of the opera and with Signorina Crusceniski on several occasions moved the large audience to a pitch of unwonted enthusiasm. Signor Oreste Benedetti's "Federico" was a very meritorious performance and in conjunction with Signorina Margherita Julia, who gave an excellent portrayal of the rather thankless, and at the same time extremely difficult, rôle of Ortroda, scored a distinct success. Signor Lodovico Contini appeared hardly sufficiently robust for the trying music of King Enrico, but his rendering was on the whole a good one. A special word of praise is also due to the "Herald," Signor F. Rosconi. Signor Giovanni Zaocani is to be congratulated on the excellence of his orchestra, and the chorus master is certainly to be complimented upon the high degree of perfection attained in his particular sphere.

div.head: Abbas Theatre, Cairo
div.p: "La Boheme."

Surely no more touching and exquisite Mimi than Signora Coniglio could be seen. Not a detail of her acting, not a least inflection of her voice but was perfect, telling, memorable, not merely for Cairo but for any stage. So quiet, so charming, knowing her world of mirth and sorrow, hunger and gaiety 80 well, no intent a listener, waiting on her lover's every word, so pathetic in her resignation and sympathy at the last, surely she moved all as she indeed moved some of us. The beauty of the 'addio' song, all its sad knowledge, and hope -"addio sospetti!"-farewell doubt and trouble, farewell sorrow, farewell all, seve pity and love.-she so well knew all love had brought and yet would bring, of happiness or unhappiness, - and the wonder of the death scene, were revealed as they seldom can be. The rest of the performance was never, one must confess it. The conductor was by no means at his best in the second act, and he missed one or two entries of the singers badly. He can do far better than that, and we must hope it will be the last occurrence of its kind. Signor Ventara was not at his best until the very end : there he excelled, and his acting was fully worthy of the situation. His make-up was most trying, and he should really pay more attention there too. The general impression as to the others, was that they could do far better; they were not at their ease, and consequently the spirit and continuity of the performance was not maintained. The 'coat' song was embarrassed and uncertain and hardly deserved the encore it obtained But then one could not but contrast it with Signor Lucenti's masterly and faultless rendering last year. Still these were all minor defects in a memorable performance. Manon Lescaut and LA Tosca are not at present being rehearsed. La Tosca should be especially noteworthy. I hope to see the three chief parts taken by Signor Coniglio, Sigtor Ventura, and Signor Challis That combination would ensure the needs of most operas and above all of La Tosca.

div.head: The German Hospital
div.p: Series of Concerts

The first concert for the benefit of the Deaconesses' Hospital, has been fixed for the 5th of February at the New Khedivial Hotel, to commence at 9.15 p.m. Among the musicians of note who will take part are Madame Stross, who, trained as a pianist at the Vienna conservatoire, is famed for her sympathetic execution ; Madame Jesumann,a mezzo-soprano with a most pleasing voice ; Dr. Stross, Dr. Frey, Mr. Jacot des Combes, and Mr. P. Ehrlich, the latter two of whom we have heard in conjunction with the famous violinist Mr. Marsick, who bas also consented to perform on this occasion. We must also mention Mix Verita, Mrs. E G.C. Moss, Mrs. Trelawney, Miss Hewat, Mr. Capozzi, and Mr. Gubsich, all of whom have promised to contribute to the programme. We trust that this concert will receive the full support which so admirable an object deserves.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: Mr. B. L. Mosely, late Judge of the Native Tribunals at Cairo, and Mrs. Mosely have given a donation of LE 50 to the Society for the Protection of Children. Mr. Hall Caine, who is staying with his wife at the Semiramis Hotel at Cairo, intends going for a trip up the Nile in company with Mr. Sidney Low, the well-known London journalist, who is making a prolonged stay in Egypt. The Right Hon. Sir Ernest Cassel entertained a select party for dinner at the restaurant of the Savoy Hotel last evening. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. Birubaum, Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Schiff, Prince and Princess Teano, Mrs. Ashley, Capt. Stirling. Mr. Webb, and Birob Pasha. At other tables were : Mr. and Mrs. Louis Tiffani and party, Mr. and Mme. Leo Foul, Baron and Baroness Sehey and party, Mr. Heaton Armstrong M.P., Marquis Fioravanti and others. Mr. and Mrs. Converse, the well-known American from New York, are staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo. Other arrivals include Baron and Baroness von Schey, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Foul, etc.

div.head: Lord Milner
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday. Lord Milner has left for Egypt.

div.head: Weather at Home
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Friday. London is enveloped in a dense fog.

div.head: Suez Notes
div.p: (From our own Correspondent.)
Suez 23rd January.

The Clayton Company's steam launch No. 2 has arrived at Suez, ready for the disinfection of steamers. The Russian Pilgrim Steamer "Gregory Morch'' which was ashore off Jeddah, and subsequently refloated by the Danish salvage steamer "Denmark", has now entered the K. M. S.S. and Graving Dock Co. dry dock at Suez for repairs. Owing to the heavy rains of late the railway line between Fayed and Nefiche stations has been seriously interrupted, and the repairs will not be completed before Friday. In the meantime, passenger trains leaving Suez for Ismailis can only go up to the undamaged place, and on the other side the Ismailia train awaits to which passengers have to walk. The goods trains have been temporarily stopped both at Ismailis and Snez.

div.head: Aerated Water for Health
div.p: The importance of pure water, for drinking purposes cannot be overestimated and overy precaution should be taken, such as redistillation, to insure protection to health. Many physicians advise drinking the ex. clusive use of carbonated or "fizz" waters, because the process of oxygenating water under pressure destroys all animate genus. The robust health of the English and the consumption of more than 4,000,000 gallons of Aerated water in 1907 indicate the value of this method of preventing epidemics. "The London Lancet, a high medical authority, in commenting upon this extensive use of effervescing beverages, stated that the effervescent properties of a liquid promote digestion in two ways-first, by the carbonic acid gas acting as a stimulant to the muscular movements of the stomach, and, second, by assisting in the disintegration of its contents. What interests most people, however, is not the scientific reasons for the extensive use of sparkling wine, like champagne, or of pare, effervescent water, like Tansan, but rather their availability and cost. "But we are learning once more in regard to water the lesson that the world has learned as to almost everything else we take into our systems; the count of purity is less than the cost of doctors' bills or than the supreme cost of death. The popular appreciation of this fact is in part reflected in the enactment of the pure food law. It is shown also in the growing use of effervescent water of assured purity and softness. A distinguished French physician says that man is as old as his arteries. Hard water hardens the arteries, soft water keeps them elastic and responsive to the pulse. Hence it is that the Japanese attribute much of their vitality, prowess, and progress to the generous use of their native sparkling water.”

div.head: BERLITZ SCHOOLS "OF LANGUAGES 335 BRANCHES.
